description:
Algoriphagus winogradskyi is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes. It was first isolated from a soil sample collected in Russia and named after the renowned microbiologist Sergei Winogradsky.

Algoriphagus winogradskyi is a Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, and aerobic bacterium. It is characterized by its rod-shaped cells, ranging in size from 0.5 to 1.5 micrometers in width and 1.5 to 5.0 micrometers in length. The cells are motile, with gliding motility, and can form reddish-orange pigmented colonies on agar plates.

Phylogenetically, Algoriphagus winogradskyi is closely related to other members of the genus Algoriphagus, which are known to be adapted to various environmental conditions, including soil, freshwater, and marine habitats.

The bacterium is considered an important contributor to the cycling of organic matter and nutrients in the environments where it is found. Its physiological and metabolic capabilities, as well as its ecological roles, are still being actively investigated by researchers in the field of microbiology.
